The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events Of thepast week. . . .'The BoMber Command had made two satisfactory attacks onSt. Nazaire and had carried out major operations against Duisbergand Berlin. 3,428 tons of. bombs had been, dropped. coastal command had carried but several attacks against U-boats. fighter command had made night attacks against German railway targets.Enemy losses for the week had been 18 destroyed, 2 probably destroyed and 11 damaged. Our losses had been 22 bombers'12 fighters and 9 Coastal Command aircraft. \\American boinbers had carried but successful attacks against. Wilhelmshaven and^Rouen."-' y In the Mediterranean our aircraft had attacked 3 U-boats andhit 8.merchant ships, 1 escort vessel and a destroyer.Our long-range bombers had attacked ports and shipping and carried out night harassing operations. American bombers had hita large ammunition ship at Palermo.There had been heavy air fighting on the Tunisian front, more,particularly in support of the Eighth Army attack on El Hamma.Hurricane Tank-busters had destroyed ' 19 tanks and damagedothers.Shipping losses for the previous week had been 111,400 tons.Our submarines had sunk two. merchant ships of 5,000 and*3,000 tons and hit two more, together with a number of small craft. 'There had been an action in the area of the Aleutian Islandsbetween United States and Japanese naval forces, but details were-not yet available.In Northern Tunisia our forces had carried out successfullocal operations despite bad weather. United States forces hadretaken Fondouk and were also east of Maknassy. By taking Gaf saand holding strong German counter-attacks in that area the americans had considerably assisted the operations of the eighth Army.The operations of the Eighth Army against the Mareth Linewere described. The latest information was that, threatened by the advance of an outflanking force which had reached El Hamma, theenemy had evacuated the Mareth position and that we had capturedMkreth, Toujane and Matmata. Over 6,000 prisoners had beentaken since the 20th March.The Prime Minister said that the Eighth Army had againperformed a very fine piece of work, and there was no doubt thatthe enemy's forces had been badly shattered.The Russians had gained some minor successes in varioussectors, but the scale of the fighting had decreased generally on all parts of the Russian front.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements.Supplies to ... 2.. At their meeting oh the 23rd February the War cabinet decided that the suspension of the restrictions oh entry into the isle of Wight and the coastal area from King's Lynn to Littlehamptonshould be continued until the 1st April, and had invited the WarOffice to formulate hew proposals^ for restrictions designed tosafeguard our preparations for offensive operations.The Secretary of State for War had circulated a Memorandum(W.P. (43) 112) proposing that a large part of-the coastline shouldbe declared, under Defence Regulation 13a, to be a Regulated Area,"within which the military authorities would have power to imposelocal restrictions; and that, in addition, there should be restric-tions on the admission of visitors to the whole of the coastal area from Hull to Land's End.The Secretary of State for the Home Department and Ministerof Home Security had also circulated a Memorandum(W.P. (43) ll6) in which, while accepting the first of theseproposals, he had summarised the arguments against the proposalfor a visitors' ban. \The War Cabinet were informed that, by the Prime Ministersdirection, the issues raised by these two Memoranda had beenconsidered by the Lord Presidents Committee.*The Lord President of the Council explained that agreement. had been reached on the basis that (except in the Isle of Wight) thevisitors' ban would not be reimposed in the areas where it was atpresent in abeyance; but an extensive area of the coast would be declared a Regulated Area, within which access to particular placesmight from time to time be restricted or completely barred by themilitary authorities, in consultation with the Regional Commis-sioner. This new system would apply to a coastal belt, 10 mileswide, from the Humber to Penzance, to the coastal area fromMilford Haven to Portishead, and to areas round the estuaries ofthe Forth, Tay and Clyde.The Prime Minister said he hoped that the military authorities would exercise due discretion in the exercise of these powers.The War Cabinet- ,(1) Took note, with approval, of the decision reached by theLord Presidents Committee.(2) Agreed that the new arrangements should be announced bythe Secretary of State for the Home Department and minister of Home Security at an early date in reply toa Private Notice Question.ElectoralReport ofCommittee.hvft Cabinet had before them a Joint Memorandunof ?Fy ? The general feeling of the War cabinet was, however, against taking a hasty decision on this matter.The War Cabinet's conclusions were as follows :-(1) A Cabinet Committee should be appointed to consider thequestions of policy raised by the Report" of theCommittee on Electoral Machinery. The Prime minister unertook to determine its composition^(2) It should be announced in the House of Commons., that theGovernment were not prepared to make emergency arrangements for improving the Register of Voters forpurposes, of war-time By-Elections in advance of their decisions on the wider questions raised in the Reportof the Committee on Electoral Machinery.(3) If there were a Debate on the application for a Writ to bemade on the following day, this announcement might bemade in the course of that Debate.
